title: 4 Cooking Methods for Tasty Plaice Dishes

steps.title: Heat up the butter in a frying pan.
steps.content: Heat up the butter in a frying pan. Use a high heat, and you will know that the pan is ready to use once the butter is foaming. A non-stick pan is best and will save you time cleaning. You can substitute oil in the place of butter if preferred. Olive oil goes well with plaice, and 2 tbsp (30 ml) is a good amount to cover the pan and fry to perfection. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Place the fillets in the pan and fry the first side for 2 minutes.
steps.content: Place the fillets in the pan and fry the first side for 2 minutes. Lay each plaice fillet flat in the frying pan. Fry for 2 minutes and then carefully flip each fillet over, and cook for another 2 minutes, or until cooked through. [2] X Research source Most frozen plaice will be sold skinless, but if you buy it fresh with the skin, start with frying the skin side down first. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Remove the fillets from the pan when cooked.
steps.content: Remove the fillets from the pan when cooked. You will be able to tell that the fillets are cooked through when they are opaque and flake easily. Place the fillets on plates to serve. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Season the pan-fried fillets as desired.
steps.content: Season the pan-fried fillets as desired. Plaice is a light, fresh fish that goes well with simple dressings. You can squeeze lemon juice, with salt and pepper to taste across the fillets for a simple seasoning. Lemon parsley butter also accompanies pan-fried plaice nicely. Combine 2 tbsp (25 g) of butter, the juice of ½ lemon, and a handful of chopped, flat-leaf parsley in a pan until hot. Drizzle over the pan-fried fillets for an easy dish. This is enough for 2 fillets. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Preheat an oven to 180°C/356°F/gas mark 4.
steps.content: Preheat an oven to 180°C/356°F/gas mark 4. Make sure that the oven is completely heated before baking the plaice fillets. This will ensure that they cook correctly. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Place the fillets in an ovenproof dish.
steps.content: Place the fillets in an ovenproof dish. A medium sized gratin dish works best for 4 fillets. Make sure that there is enough room for each, and that they are not overlapping at any point. [7] X Research source Use a light coating of oil or butter to cover the dish. Baking paper also works well and reduces the mess to clean up afterward.

steps.title: Season the fillets in the oven dish.
steps.content: Season the fillets in the oven dish. Combine the lemon juice, chopped parsley, flaked almonds, and olive oil to make a salsa-type dressing. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Bake the fillets uncovered for 10-15 minutes.
steps.content: Bake the fillets uncovered for 10-15 minutes. The time depends on the size of the fillets, and how cold the ingredients are to begin with. When the fish is cooked through, remove from the oven and leave resting for 1 minute, before transferring onto a serving plate. [9] X Research source You can tell that the fillets are cooked through when you make an incision in the middle of the fish, it looks opaque, rather than translucent like when it’s raw. Cooked fish will also easily break into flakes when it’s done. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Combine the ingredients for the breadcrumb coating.
steps.content: Combine the ingredients for the breadcrumb coating. Beat together the egg and milk in one bowl to make an egg wash. Then mix together the flour with salt and pepper to taste in a separate bowl. Put the breadcrumbs out on another plate. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Dip the fillets into the breadcrumb coating.
steps.content: Dip the fillets into the breadcrumb coating. Dip each plaice fillet into the flour mixture, and shake off any excess. Then dip each fillet into the egg wash. Finally, place the fillets into the breadcrumbs and coat fully. [12] X Research source Coating the plaice fillets in the breadcrumb coating can be done ahead of time if necessary, and then refrigerated. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Pan-fry the plaice fillets for 2 minutes on the first side.
steps.content: Pan-fry the plaice fillets for 2 minutes on the first side. Heat up a frying pan over a medium heat with the olive oil. Place the fillets in the frying pan, being careful not to overcrowd the pan. Flip the fillets after 2 minutes, and fry the other side for an additional 2 minutes or until coloured lightly on both sides. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Remove the fillets from the pan when crispy and golden.
steps.content: Remove the fillets from the pan when crispy and golden. You will be able to tell that the plaice are cooked through when the flesh has changed from translucent to opaque. The breadcrumb coating will become golden. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Rinse the fish in water.
steps.content: Rinse the fish in water. Use cool running water to gently rinse off the plaice, which removes any sand or grit if it's freshly caught. Make sure to wash your hands well before and after to avoid spreading bacteria around your kitchen. [16] X Research source To dry the plaice after rinsing, pat it dry with a paper towel. This also helps to keep the fish from getting tough or mushy when you cook it. [17] X Research source

steps.title: Trim off the fins.
steps.content: Trim off the fins. Use a pair of kitchen scissors to snip off the plaice fins. You can leave the tail on to create an impressive appearance for your dish. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Slash the plaice skin with a sharp knife.
steps.content: Slash the plaice skin with a sharp knife. Make a long slash down the spine, and then 6 diagonal slashes stemming from it, with 3 each side. This makes the fish crispy. [19] X Research source Make the slashes on the top side of the fish, which for flatfish such as plaice, is the side that it’s eyes are on. The incisions should be deep, but not go entirely through the fish. About 1 centimeter (0.4 in) deep works well. [20] X Research source

steps.title: Season the plaice.
steps.content: Season the plaice. Brush the olive oil generously over the whole fish. Then season to taste with salt, pepper, and lemon juice. [21] X Research source

steps.title: Put the plaice under a hot grill for 8-10 minutes.
steps.content: Put the plaice under a hot grill for 8-10 minutes. Place the plaice in an ovenproof dish, and grill using a medium heat. A larger fish may take a few minutes longer. [22] X Research source You don’t need to turn the fish during the grilling process, as it will cook evenly through. [23] X Research source Grilling with a medium heat works best for fish. This is because a heat too low won’t adequately cook the fish, but a heat too high will cause some parts to dry out and others to not cook fast enough. [24] X Research source

steps.title: Lift the fillets off the skeleton when cooked.
steps.content: Lift the fillets off the skeleton when cooked. Use a fish knife and fork to pull away the two top fillets from the skeleton. Then you can simply remove the skeleton by gently easing it out like a zipper. This will leave the two bottom fillets in the dish, also ready to serve. [25] X Research source You will be able to tell when the plaice is done because the flesh will be opaque and come easily away from the bone. [26] X Research source
